pros: The organization has a great mission and does amazing life-saving work. Colleagues are mostly collaborative, supportive and kind. It's pretty amazing for a large organization. The organization has been going through a series of difficult transitions, for at least the past 6 years now, and I appreciate the effort made to improve diversity and inclusion, work-life balance, and well-being in recent years. This progress seems slow compared to the way things move in the private sector, but I know staff are stretched and I am grateful. My hiring supervisor was very proactive about supporting work-life balance, well-being, and ensuring we had the support we needed. This person is a big part of why I agreed to work with CRC. Despite the cons below, I feel that everyone, including the most senior executives, are doing their best within their capabilities.
cons: In my experience, HR practices have been mixed and questionable. During the hiring process, I was promised significant funding for professional development and time off during a difficult time in my life (for a specified time period). After being hired, when I tried to claim that, I received mixed support as my supervisor had changed multiple times. Change is inevitable. However, it wasn't well handled, with little to no acknowledgment that this is an accident/oversight, which in addition to other issues, has made me feel a little de-humanized. This sort of culture has endured for nearly a year, though I have seen improvements that give some hope. As with many workplaces during COVID-19, staff turnover has been high for a variety of reasons and morale has been low based on team-wide surveys, though this has improved as of the last survey in Dec 2022. Of the approximately 12 people I work with the most, only 2 remain. Some folks are overwhelmed with work, though the workload varies. It has often felt hard to feel motivated, engaged and desiring to continue here. Philanthropy is all about building relationships with our donors, yet it seems that relationships within our teams are not sufficiently prioritized. Support varies wildly based on your supervisor, and I've observed that new hires unfortunately lack support to do their job, let alone support their own direct reports. To my knowledge, only SLTs get in-person opportunities to meet for work. It seems smaller teams may no longer have in-person opportunities to meet, not even just once a year (CDO and my supervisor have shared conflicting messages to date).

review_title: Great Company but Philanthropy not so great
pros: Great company that does real humanitarian work
cons: Unfortunately ever since the previous CMDO left, the Philanthropy has gone down the rabbit hole. One only has to look at how the new CDO's posts on LinkedIn which has virtually zero support to understand how unpopular she is. She literally laid off well respected staff that have been with CRC for decades for speaking up, tolerated bullying behaviors and essentially became the driving force behind a very toxic work environment. Philanthropy still produces $$$, but much thanks to the pandemic, the war and Red Cross legacy, not her leadership. It's truly astonishing how many people from Philanthropy have left CRC within the two years since Ronan left. It's now a completely different team because she could not command respect. What a shame

pros: Training content relevant and beneficial

Missing pay and unanswered emailed and feedback when one has questions and demands answers as to why employees pay is missing CRC does what they want while the employees are missing their pay cycles/deposits? The Canadian Red Cross, President & CEO earnes-$321,299- annually, would be interesting to see what would transpire if he was missing his pay ? Very rude CRC employees HR-on the phone. Not much of a role model representative of a humanitarian mission? Why would anyone want to remain an employee with the CRC when your pay is gone missing repeatedly. Missing pay and lack of concise answers and accountability is a deal-breaker. I question the integrity of the entire organization. If Ottawa has allocated 100-million in funding for the CRC emergency management, I question why these funds are being mismanaged? Can we really expect anything less ? Crooks are a dime a dozen!

review_title: Great Organization / Managers need some work
pros: Great organization, great reputation from the Canadian public, excellent use of funds for important projects.  Generally good at removing the slackers and making room for performers. This is refreshing, and keeps people on track.  Human resource team was fantastic when I was hired - very little bureaucracy. Hiring additional staff was also very easy once budgets were approved. Organization hires for good 'fit' up front which helps enormously when the stress ramps up and you need to count on a strong team.
cons: VPs are well qualified but don't take full advantage of the talent they have on hand. Some managers are inept at managing and, again, limit opportunities to make the most out of their talented staff. CEO is only concerned about building up his resume to position himself for his next big role.  Pay is low / at non-profit levels but project work and flexible work arrangements generally make up for it. The Quebec team has undue influence on country-wide decisions and hiring. Sometimes seems like two Red Crosses in one country which is contrary to the standards we set for ourselves in countries across the world. e.g. Quebec is the only team that has their own branding -"Canadian Red Cross - Quebec Team" -emblazoned on their jackets. No other provinces brand themselves and shouldn't.

job_title: Outreach Coordinator for Disaster Management in Lloydminster, SK
pros: So many great reasons to work with the CRC, the support they offer to so many families, wether it's a personal disaster or a large scale disaster, comfort each family means truly that.  I thoroughly am impressed with the idea of 'one red cross', and working together from province to province.  I work at a border city of two provinces, and have seen how we pull together.  I have also been impressed with the training that is given, top notch.  And how could I forget the amazing staff who diligently work hard.
cons: I don't really have any cons, other than breaks my heart to see people going through the pain of losing homes etc.  Self Care is such an important aspect of what we do.  As a former police officer, I know the ramifications of not dealing with post-trauma events.  It is of highest importance that staff are trained and have good knowledge of their options post-events.

review_title: Most people at CRC are overworked, stressed, and unmotivated
pros: The mission of the organization is great.
cons: CRC has a beautiful mission and attracts really great and dedicated staff. Unfortunately, it abuses people’s motivation and imposes on them horrible working conditions. Contracts are almost always temporary (3 months, 6 months…) until they are obliged by law to make you permanent. While a temp, you have almost no benefits at all (incl. no pension contributions). People are forced to do overtime and they are expected to not declare them. Salaries are much below the average in the not-for-profit sector. Even when one has stood with them long enough to become permanent, they only offer 6-month mat leave and zero top-up. Internal processes are a mess and it’s a highly bureaucratic organization, meaning that a lot of workarounds are needed, systems are inefficient, and everything works at an incredibly slow pace. In an environment where quick action is needed, it is the employees that pay the price: most people are overworked, stressed, and unmotivated. HR is not helpful at all in solving conflicts and tends to either ignore that a problem exists, or make them even worse. The turnover is very high, and often that leads to a huge loss of institutional memory, making it harder for new staff's onboarding. It’s a pity, because the mission of the organization is great.

pros:
There are some great people working there who are really devoted to the 'cause' and their work. 
GREAT digital marketing team!!!!
cons:
The Philanthropy department needs another revamp. There are too many people stuck in old ways. There is no room for growth. Senior management cannot seem to 'clue in' when there are issues that need to be addressed. Especially HR matters. Lack of professionalism. No respect for hierarchy. I was told minutes after my second interview to look on AFP's job board for similar roles in other organization. Needles to say I thought I did horribly at the interview and had no chance. Not a welcoming environment. 
Was told several times by a senior director "let me know if I'm too bossy. I'm known to be miss bossy pants". 
Too many people trying to impress lead of the org. Lacks focus.

pros:
Flexible hours, pleasant work environment, good benefits, training,Multi-faceted, fast paced, diverse and very rewarding.

I learned much about needs not only in my province but in a World wide capacity. Giving BACK is so important and encourages others to do the same...very rewarding

My co-workers were mostly volunteers, but I did appreciate my supervisor and manager;as they helped with guidance and mentoring at times, but were not pro-active in my day-to-day job, with the exception of making critism.
cons: The most difficult part of the job was actually finding the 'balance' between work and personal time. Although we were paid a decent salary and had really excellent benefit package, the additional time put into the job on extra activities such as meetings, fund raisers and in times of crisis... make it difficult to find balance at t imes. Also I found the political climate of the Organization fraught with negativity. Personalities should NOT come into play, particularly with this type of non-for-profit organization.

pros:
Non- profit attracts good, and talented employees-  makes for excellent co-workers  & volunteers
reasonable  start wages, good Insurance coverage  and RRSP for full time
relaxed office environment - excellent for those used to self employment( self starters)
cons:
Corporate culture lacks strong, respected direction - 
A tight gathering of flatulent management in place - 
Infantile in objectives, and directives, and follow up
Employees become accustomed to shortcomings rather than strive for improvements

job_title: Home Help Worker in Sudbury, ON
pros: The amazing flexibility : I get final say in hours, area of town, and selection of clients for me (non smokers, etc.).  The office/support staff is amazing and always smiling and helpful.  You also get to meet amazing people every day who have lived different lives and made different choices from you.  Every day is interesting. Great company to work for!
cons: You ARE working for people who are elderly and/or infirm, who have medical issues.  This can be tough to encounter - especially when you have been with them for a long time.  There is always the possibility of losing a client who has become a friend.

review_title: I get to help people, make a difference in the world and get paid for it.
pros: They do what they say they will do. They spend their public funds in an ethical, transparent manner. People involved with the Canadian Red Cross (and any Red Cross society) are part of a vast, world-wide movement that makes the world a better place every single day.
cons: When the wrong person is in a position, action isn't taken quickly enough to remove them or move them somewhere else. This affects moral in a huge way. Also, during events like appeals for worldwide disasters, we are expected to work very long hours without getting fully compensated for it.

review_title: Community Services Assistant & First Aid Instructor
job_title: Community Services Assistant & First Aid Instructor in Richmond Hill, ON
pros:
I don't know if this is exclusive to the branch I work at, but I found people at the York Region branch are so friendly, very helpful and supportive, extremely organized and just great people to work with overall. Great learning environment and everyone is willing to teach you new things, as long as you ask. From who I've worked with and spoke with at the Toronto Branch, everyone is also very kind ! I very much believe in the organizations 7 fundamental principles and the mission of the organization. I am also a Disaster Management Volunteer for the Canadian Red Cross.

As an instructor, there were multiple opportunities to join workshops on how to teach better and various trainings . Found these really useful and it was nice to meet other instructors
cons: the CRC is going through a "re-structuring" in the next few years, so there isn't a lot of room to move up.

pros: Lots of great people work for this organization and they offer very good benefits to employees.
cons: Pay is usually very low outside of management level and there's zero transparency where salaries are concerned. People doing the same job in different parts of Canada can be paid vastly (as much as 30%) different amounts and women make less than men on average at this level. There's also a bit of an "us and them" culture between the leadership and everyone else. Ultimately it was a disappointment place to work. There are very limited opportunities to move up or to train for anything else. There were some online training opportunities, but you had to  do it in your own time and they weren't very useful programs.

review_title: Too many chefs; not enough sous-chefs
pros:
The staff are wonderful; so generous of spirit.... and the volunteers and what they do, sometimes in areas where they risk their lives...'volunteering'   That blows my mind! 
Also the benefits and group RRSP plans are second to none.
cons: This company is management heavy.  In my experience and others I worked closely with agreed, top management ensured that whomever they wanted hired was, whether they were family or just friends.  The result can mean current staff having to use part of their time to continuously train or cover for these people.

job_title: Personal Support Worker in Woodstock, NB
pros:
It is a wonderful and fulfilling job. We get to work with some enjoyable great people, and Seniors
We work with Seniors to get them to be able to stay in their homes longer and enjoy their freedom
longer.
cons:
The only downside, I have found is that we get to meet these great seniors, too late in life, because they
are great people, and when we loose a client, it is like loosing a part of your family, as you have gotten
to take care and spend time , with these people, and we get to know them too late in life.They are sadly 
missed when we loose a client.

pros: Great project and program work. Some great, hard working colleagues. CIO is great. Connection to the International Red Cross world is a plus -there is always something interesting going on and you feel connected to Canadian and worldwide humanitarian efforts. Technology is generally modern and progressive even given the non-profit budget. Remote work is smooth. Office and work spaces on Cooper street are fantastic. Plenty of meeting rooms, great workstations, modern layout, great lunch room/ cafeteria with free coffee. The coffee machine attracts everyone which really improves collaboration. Organizational reputation is strong which opens a lot of doors. Benefits are pretty good.
cons: No performance management and no transparency on promotion / career path. Once you start, you are given no awareness of what the next level is , what salary is possible, etc. There is no performance management system and no bonus system whatsoever. Overtime is not paid, period - unless you are in Quebec. Years pass and your salary stays static and HR shrugs their shoulders. The HR shop has been restructured many times over the years with little vision on worker retention. The fund raising unit, while effective, is run by a bully who does whatever he wants. Another software dev shop was stood up which , in effect, created three separate IT shops. The CEO/CFO don't know a thing about IT. They have cost the organization millions in poor oversight. The CEO has given cushy management roles to friends at the expense of the organization. A little too much neopotism for my taste.

pros: I have volunteered here for 3+years at the Health Equipment Loan Program. This program is vitally needed in the community and is not something anyone thinks of until something goes wrong and they need it. The people here are fantastic. The organizational structure is excellent. This service is worth your time.
cons: Sometimes there is a lack of volunteers, but the dedicated one pick up the slack. Please volunteer or work here.

review_title: Good Attempt at Work Life Balance
pros:
Good work life balance for an emergency response organization especially
Good equitable pay
Chances to improve, grow and be promoted
cons:
Some toxic work culture demanding prioritizing work over mental health and family
Some toxic work culture through persistence of blind hierarchy as opposed to the matrix which is the attempted structure

review_title: Some good colleagues but toxic office culture and no accountability of Sr. Managers
job_title: Human Resources Manager in Sarnia, ON
pros: Smart, ambitious, diverse colleagues at lower levels.
cons: Heavily bureaucratic and very hierarchical, no accountability for upper management, poor management.

job_title: Großkundenmanager / Gebietsleiter Österreich in Sudbury, ON
pros: Great place to work.  They are a family oriented company and take good care of their employees with a positive work/life balance.
cons: The pay is not the greatest and you only get 70 hour paychecks, however the atmosphere is great and weighs out the cons.

review_title: nonjudgmental review to help management and candidates
pros:
- flexible hours and work arrangements
- holidays and vacation time
- benefits
cons:
- salaries are not compatible with the job market
- salaries for the same positions are not standardized based on qualifications and experience
- hiring and promotion process is not clear most of the time and in certain departments
- too many changes can happen in a short time without proper communication

pros: it use to be the best place to work for, i loved the clients.If we wore good to them , they wore good to us.
cons: over the tears thinks got worse, the government changed to many things , & it was not for the better, it got worse every year.

job_title: Personal Support Worker in Sault Ste. Marie, ON
pros: i work for the assisted living program for the canadian red cross i love my job because i love helping the elderly with there daily living.  i have been working for 5 years in this field and its a inspiration and it put a smile on my face daily! thanks
cons: travel time and not having benefits after your probation

job_title: Human Resources/VR Coordinator in Toronto, ON
pros: Working for one of the best nonprofit organizations is a good experience. I have met many great people with great experiences. It's also good to make contributions to the Canadian society.
cons: Have to get used to say goodbye to a large amount of people in short period because each person in a disaster only stays for maximum of 3 weeks.

review_title: I really liked the people I worked with
pros: I like the care for the clts and the people I worked with. I like the hours I worked. I was really inform and updated on all inservices.
cons: I didn't like when we went to red cross care partners and then care partners. If had a chose I would stay with Canadian red cross.

pros: Very professional organization  -  they practice what they preach.  Very accepting of all.
cons: Too many term jobs - difficult to get permanency

review_title: Don't work in this position if you value your mental health
job_title: Emergency Management Coordinator in Prince George, BC
pros: Working with and learning from the volunteers who volunteer their personal time to assist those in need at all hours of the day & night.
cons: Overworked, underpaid and with unrealistic expectations this job falls short when it comes to any professional growth. For a company that provides so much to people in need they truly neglect to take care of their own employees. Priorities are skewed and mismanaged. Turn over is high due to these reasons.

job_title: Technical Advisor, Gender in Ottawa, ON
pros: An organization open to change in gender equality and social inclusion topics, member of a global movement, open to localization, able to leverage significant funds, already has a remote work force
cons: Large organization so change is slow, systems and tools in gender equality and social inclusion lacking, not unionized, parental leave policy undesirable
